skill.name: agent-browser
skill.description: Automates browser interactions for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction. Use when the user needs to navigate websites, interact with web pages, fill forms, take screenshots, test web applications, or extract information from web pages.
skill.summary: Automates browser interactions for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction.
skill.author: vercel-labs

security_audit.summary: All 57 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted documentation examples (backtick syntax in markdown) as shell execution code, example URLs as network exfiltration, and standard browser automation features (cookies, storage, session state) as credential access. This is a legitimate browser automation CLI tool from Vercel Labs.

content.user_title: Automate Browser Interactions for Web Tasks
content.value_statement: Manual browser testing and data extraction consume significant developer time. The agent-browser skill enables programmatic browser automation for testing workflows, form filling, screenshots, and web content extraction through a simple command-line interface.
actual_capabilities: Navigate websites and automate click, fill, and scroll interactions
Take full-page screenshots and save as image or PDF files
Extract text, HTML, and element attributes from web pages
Save and restore browser state for authenticated session testing
Mock network requests and intercept API responses
Record browser interactions as video for debugging and demos
limitations: Cannot bypass CAPTCHAs or authentication barriers on protected sites
Limited to single browser instance per session without explicit session flags
Does not support browser extensions or download automation
JavaScript evaluation is limited to read-only expressions

use_cases.title: Automated Web Application Testing
use_cases.description: Test web application workflows by automating form submissions, navigation flows, and user interactions. Verify pages load correctly and capture screenshots at key steps.
use_cases.target_user: QA engineers and developers building web applications

use_cases.title: Web Data Extraction and Research
use_cases.description: Extract structured data from websites by navigating pages, locating elements, and capturing text content. Save results for analysis or database input.
use_cases.target_user: Data analysts and researchers gathering web content

use_cases.title: Visual Regression Testing and Documentation
use_cases.description: Capture screenshots of web pages at various viewport sizes to document designs or detect visual regressions across updates.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Page Navigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agent-browser to open https://example.com, take a snapshot of interactive elements, and tell me what forms and buttons are available on the page.
prompt_templates.scenario: Discover page structure and available actions

prompt_templates.title: Form Automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to the login page at {url}, fill in the email field with test@example.com, fill in the password field, and submit the form. Wait for the page to load after submission.

prompt_templates.title: Screenshot Capture
prompt_templates.prompt: Open {url}, set the viewport to 1920x1080, take a full-page screenshot, and save it to {output_path}.png
prompt_templates.scenario: Capture visual documentation of web pages

prompt_templates.title: Stateful Testing Session
prompt_templates.prompt: Open the app at {app_url}, load the saved state from {state_file}, navigate to the dashboard, and verify the user is logged in by checking the page title and URL.
prompt_templates.scenario: Test authenticated user flows using saved session state

output_examples.input: agent-browser open https://example.com/form && agent-browser fill @e1 "user@example.com" && agent-browser fill @e2 "password123" && agent-browser click @e3

best_practices: Use element references (@e1, @e2) from snapshots rather than brittle CSS selectors for reliable automation
Re-snapshot after page navigation or significant DOM changes since element references may change
Save browser state after successful authentication to speed up repeated testing sessions
Use the --json flag when parsing output programmatically for reliable machine-readable results
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode credentials in scripts; use environment variables or secure credential storage
Do not skip waiting for network idle after form submissions, which may cause intermittent failures
Do not rely on element positions or indexes; always use semantic references from snapshots
Do not test against production systems without explicit permission and appropriate safeguards

faq.question: What browsers does agent-browser support?
faq.answer: agent-browser uses the system Chromium browser. It automatically downloads the required browser binaries on first run.

faq.question: Can agent-browser run in headless mode?
faq.answer: Yes, by default it runs headless. Use the --headed flag to see the browser window during debugging.

faq.question: How do I handle dynamic content that loads slowly?
faq.answer: Use the wait command with various conditions: wait for element appearance, wait for specific text, wait for URL patterns, or wait for network idle state.

faq.question: Can I test authenticated flows?
faq.answer: Yes, login once, then use 'agent-browser state save auth.json' to save the authenticated session. Load it with 'agent-browser state load auth.json' in future sessions.

faq.question: How do I extract data from multiple pages?
faq.answer: Loop through navigation and extraction steps. Use the --json flag for output that can be parsed by scripts or Claude Code workflows.

faq.question: Is agent-browser safe to use on any website?
faq.answer: Only use on websites you own or have permission to test. Respect robots.txt and terms of service. Avoid testing on sites with strict anti-automation policies.
